Going from window hoarders to tab hoarders

Imagine clicking a link and having a new window pop up, quickly filling your screen with overlapping windows, each competing for your attention. How much time would you waste searching for the right page?

Consider how this chaos would affect your daily tasks, research, and social media interactions. Believe it or not, before tabbed browsing, this was the norm!

With tabs, we can open multiple web pages in a single window, switch between them effortlessly, and maintain focus without losing track of our online activities. This simple feature has reshaped our digital lives. Where did tabbed browsing come from? And how did it shape the way we browse the web today?

The Birth of tabbed browsing

The concept of tabs in computing dates back to the early 1980s, with the WordVision DOS word processor being one of the first commercially available products to feature a tabbed interface.

However, it wasn’t until the late 1990s that tabs became web browsers.

“InternetWorks released in 1994. Tabbed browsing also appeared in NetCaptor, an Internet Explorer shell created by Adam Stiles in 1997.”
